data.title: Consultation Official Roles/Responsibilites, Dispute Resolution
data.subtitle: Regional Foresters, Stations Directors, and the Area Director
data.landingpagecontent:
1. Fulfill, within the Forest Service's mission areas, the Government's trust responsibilities and treaty obligations.
  2. Coordinate and collaborate with Tribes in the early development of policies and decisions that may have tribal implications.
  3. Establish and implement effective Tribal Relations Programs for their Units
  4. Develop effective, timely communication between the Forest Serivice Office of Tribal Relations in Washington, D.C., Regional Tribal Relations Program Managers, Research and Development (R&D) Tribal Liaisons, and Forest Grassland and Prairie Tribal Liaisons
  5. Designate employees to serve as a focal point for the Unit's contact between Tribes at the Regional, Station, or the Area level.
  6. Ensure that Tribes with rights and interests that cross more than one Region, Forest, Station, the Area or other Units have one primary point of contact between the Forest Service and the Tribe.
  7. Ensure tribal program management interests are represented in the decision making process of the National and Regional Leadership teams.
  8. Ensure that consultation is conducted with Tribes for Regional, Station and the Area decisions and actions that may affect Tribes.
  9. Ensure that the recommendations from the Report to the Secretary of Agriculture, USDA Policy and Procedures Review and Recommendations: Indian Sacred Sites and similar recommendations are implemented efficiently, effectively, and thoroughly throughout their Region, Station, and the Area.
  10. Ensure appropriate repatriation of human remains, associated funerary objects, unassociated funerary objects, sacred objects, and objects of cultural patrimony from National Forests under their jurisdiction.
  11. Support reburial of repatriated human remains and cultural items on National Forest System lands consistent with uses on the national Forest System land as determined necessary for management of the National Forest System.
  12. Provide funding and training to Units in support of Tribal Relations work.

data.title: Regional Foresters
data.subtitle: Regional Foresters, Stations Directors, and the Area Director
data.landingpagecontent:
1. Fulfill, within the Forest Service's mission areas, the Government's trust responsibilities and treaty obligations.
  2. Coordinate and collaborate with Tribes in the early development of policies and decisions that may have tribal implications.
  3. Establish and implement effective Tribal Relations Programs for their Units
  4. Develop effective, timely communication between the Forest Serivice Office of Tribal Relations in Washington, D.C., Regional Tribal Relations Program Managers, Research and Development (R&D) Tribal Liaisons, and Forest Grassland and Prairie Tribal Liaisons
  5. Designate employees to serve as a focal point for the Unit's contact between Tribes at the Regional, Station, or the Area level.
  6. Ensure that Tribes with rights and interests that cross more than one Region, Forest, Station, the Area or other Units have one primary point of contact between the Forest Service and the Tribe.
  7. Ensure tribal program management interests are represented in the decision making process of the National and Regional Leadership teams.
  8. Ensure that consultation is conducted with Tribes for Regional, Station and the Area decisions and actions that may affect Tribes.
  9. Ensure that the recommendations from the Report to the Secretary of Agriculture, USDA Policy and Procedures Review and Recommendations: Indian Sacred Sites and similar recommendations are implemented efficiently, effectively, and thoroughly throughout their Region, Station, and the Area.
  10. Ensure appropriate repatriation of human remains, associated funerary objects, unassociated funerary objects, sacred objects, and objects of cultural patrimony from National Forests under their jurisdiction.
  11. Support reburial of repatriated human remains and cultural items on National Forest System lands consistent with uses on the national Forest System land as determined necessary for management of the National Forest System.
  12. Provide funding and training to Units in support of Tribal Relations work.

data.title: Regional Tribal Relations Program Managers
data.landingpagecontent:
1. Ensure that tribal interests and rights are considered and integrated across program areas and that government-to-government relations between Tribes and Forest Service Administrative Units are conducted in compliance with applicable laws, Executive Orders, and Agency policy.
  2. Collaborate with other Federal agencies, Tribes, and American Indian advocacy organizations to implement programs and projects and seek mutually beneficial opportunities.
  3. Serve as the Region's primary source of advice and assistance on matters involving tribal relations; including advising line and staff on responses to tribal requests for use of National Forest System lands and resources.
  4. Brief and coach Line Officers, Forest, Grassland, and Prairie Tribal Liaisons, key staff, and appropriate specialists on effective communication and cultural knowledge and skills required for effective government-to-government relationships between the Forest Service and Tribes and tribal organizations.
  5. Monitor Forest Service programs to ensure that tribal governments are consulted when land and resource management plans and/or other actions could affect tribal rights and interests.
  6. See to reconcile different views and facilitate timely resolution of disputes involving Tribes and the Forest Service that cannot be resolved at the local level.
  7. Advise line and staff on their responsibilities to:
    1. Fulfill, within the Forest Service's mission areas, the Government's trust responsibilities and treaty obligations.
    2. Protect sacred sites and archaeological, historical and cultural resources.
    3. Accommodate Indian religious and spiritual values and practices to the maximum extent, practicable, permitted by law, and not clearly inconsistent with agency functions.
    4. Respond to tribal requests for reburial of human remains in coordination with the Heritage Resources Progam Manager.
    5. Explain off-reservation treaty rights that affect Forest Service-administered land management.
    6. Seek traditional knowledge that may be relevant to the management of natural and cultural resources.
  8. Coordinate and facilitate a Tribal Relations program of training at the Regional and local levels that includes the elements of Indian law and policy, consultation, Federal-Tribal relations, sacred sites protection and cultural awareness.
  9. Collect and submit information to the Director of the Forest Service Office of Tribal relations in Washington, D.C. and the U.S. Department of Agriculture, Office of Tribal Relations that summarizes the issues and outcomes of consultations with Tribal Governments within their respective Regions or Administrative Units, as requested by Forest Service Office of Tribal Relations in Washington, D.C.       
  10. Collect and annually submit information to the Director of the Forest Service Office of Tribal Relations in Washington, DC that summarizes the issues and outcomes of tribal relations efforts across the Region, to be included in a national annual end-of-year report. 11. Serve on the National Tribal Relations Team, led by the Director of the Forest Service Office of Tribal Relations in Washington, DC, to coordinate policy development, program reviews and improvement, and project support across the Agency.
  11. Serve on National Tribal Relations Team, led by the Director of the Forest Service Office of Tribal Relations, in Washington, D.C. to coordinate policy development, program reviews and improvement and project support across the Agency.
  12. Coordinate and provide Agency staff work necessary for processing requests by Indian tribes and lineal descendants for reburial of human remains and/or cultural items. Provide documentation, budget and briefing materials necessary for management decisions and reporting.  Initiate program and reburial activity reviews necessary to provide quality controls and tribal relations feedback.
  13. Conduct periodic reviews to ensure compliance with the Forest Service reburial policy pursuant to requirements of the Cultural and Heritage Cooperation Authority of 2008.

data.title: Forest, Grassland, and Prairie Supervisors Responsibilities
data.landingpagecontent:
1. Fulfill, within the Forest Service's mission areas, the Government's responsibilities and treaty obligations.
  2. Coordinate and collaborate with Tribes in the early development of policies and decisions that may have tribal implications.
  3. Serve as the Consultation Official on the Unit. This requires being personally engaged in the consultation process with Tribes.
  4. Identify a Forest, Grassland, or Prairie Tribal Liaison to serve as the first point of contact with tribal leaders and as the person who will generally initiate Agency contact with Tribes.
  5. In partnership with tribal officials, develop agreed-upon protocols for consultation on issues and decisions that may have a direct, substantial effect on tribal lands, subsistence uses, treaty rights, sacred sites, or cultural resources or practices on and off reservations.
  6. Ensure that activities relating to Tribes are reported to the Regional Office, through the Regional Tribal Relations Program Manager, for inclusion in an annual end-of-year report to be delivered to the Forest Service Office of Tribal Relations in Washington, DC.

data.title: District Rangers
data.landingpagecontent:
1. Implement and maintain the Tribal Relations Program within their area of authority, including staffing.
  2. Serve as the consultation official on the Unit when delegated that authority by the Forest Supervisor. This requires being personally engaged in the consultation process with Tribes.

data.title: National Forest, Grassland and Prairies Tribal Liaisons
data.landingpagecontent:
1. Support their Unit and especially their Line Officer's efforts regarding tribal consultation, coordination, and collaboration.
  2. Serve as the Unit primary staff point of contact for developing and maintaining relationships with Tribes.
  3. Maintain the Unit's input to the USDA Tribal Consultation Database.
  4. Serve as the Unit subject matter expert in providing information, training, and assistance to personnel across the Unit regarding working with American Indian and/or Alaska Native tribes and Alaska Native Corporations
  5. Assist the Regional Tribal Relations Program Manager in their responsibilities and activities, including end-of-year reporting.

data.title: Roles and Responsibilities
data.landingpagecontent:
1. Support their Unit and especially their Line Officer's efforts regarding tribal consultation, coordination, and collaboration.
  2. Serve as the Unit primary staff point of contact for developing and maintaining relationships with Tribes.
  3. Maintain the Unit's input to the USDA Tribal Consultation Database.
  4. Serve as the Unit subject matter expert in providing information, training, and assistance to personnel across the Unit regarding working with American Indian and/or Alaska Native tribes and Alaska Native Corporations
  5. Assist the Regional Tribal Relations Program Manager in their responsibilities and activities, including end-of-year reporting.

data.title: Administrative Review
data.subtitle: USDA Departmental Regulation
data.landingpagecontent:
1. Several Forest Service administrative review procedures are available to individual tribal members and Tribal governments who have met the eligibility requirements of the applicable procedure.
  2. Eligibility is established by submitting specific comments during a public comment opportunity for a Forest Service proposed project or land management plan.
  3. Under the administrative review procedures for project and activity decisions implementing a land management plan (36 CFR 218), Federally-recognized Indian tribes and Alaska Native Corporations can also meet the eligibility requirements when specific written comments as defined in 36 CFR 218.2 are provided during Federal-Tribal consultations.

data.title: Dispute Resolution
data.subtitle: USDA Departmental Regulation
data.landingpagecontent:
Pursuant to and consistent with DR §1350-002 An Indian tribe may seek conflict resolution through the U.S. Department of Agriculture’s Office of Tribal Relations when:

  1. An Indian tribe engaged in consultation believes that the Forest Service has not appropriately or adequately considered the needs, desires, or requests of the Tribe, or
  2. An Indian tribe believes the Forest Service should engage with them in consultation and the Forest Service has not done so.

data.title: Delegation
data.landingpagecontent:
1. Line Officers should engage personally with tribal leaders.
  2. This direction is not intended to minimize the importance of staff-to-staff communication and collaboration. On the contrary, staff interactions are essential to set the stage for effective consultation and should be maintained and enhanced.
  3. The staff or unit responsible for planning the consultation may request technical assistance from the Forest Service Office of Tribal Relations in Washington, DC or from Tribal Relations Specialists.

data.title: Consultation
data.landingpagecontent:
The Forest Service, like other Federal agencies, has a duty to consult and coordinate with Indian tribes on a government-to-government basis, as directed in Executive Order 13175, Consultation and Coordination with Indian Tribal Governments

  1. When there is a “substantial direct effect” to one of more Tribes or ANCs from the proposed decision or action, consultation must be initiated.
  2. When there are possible effects, consider the geographical extent of those effects. For instance, if an action or activity is confined to National Forest System lands, evaluate which Tribes or ANCs have connections to, or benefit from, those lands. Or, if a decision or action has a State-wide effect, but primarily on forested lands typically within the jurisdiction of State and Private Forestry, evaluate which Tribes or ANCs have cultural or historic connections to those lands.
  3. When determining which Tribes or ANCs to consult with, check with intertribal organizations or other agencies which may have conducted consultation on similar actions or activities in the past. The National Park Service NAGPRA database may give an indication of which Tribes have an interest in a specific location.
  4. Line Officers should engage personally with Tribal leaders.
  5. Staff interactions are essential to set the stage for effective consultation and should be maintained and enhances and should be maintained and enhanced.
  6. The staff or unit responsible for planning the consultation may request technical assistance from the forest service Office of Tribal Relations in Washington, D.C. or from Tribal Relations Specialist.
  7. Government-to-government consultation may only occur between Forest Service Line Officers and Tribal leaders who have authority to consult on behalf of their Tribe.
    • This direction is not intended to minimize the importance of staff-to-staff communication and collaboration. This section only indicates that staff may not serve as the Forest Service Consulting Official in government-to-government consultations.
  8. Minimum Consultation Period. Widely applicable national issues must provide a consultation period of at least 120 days from the date the Indian tribe or Alaska Native Corporation likely received the information on which they are being invited to consult. Allow an additional 14 days for delivery time if the notification is by postal service.
  9. Other actions (such as consultation on national issues that may affect only one or a few Indian tribes or ANCs, or on regional or more local decisions) may require less time for consultation.

Documentation Consultation

  1. Database entry. All consultation events must be entered into the USDA Tribal Consultation Database.
  2. Record Maintenance. Each staff or Unit conducting consultations shall maintain a consultation record for each consultation.
  3. Program Reviews. Consultation monitoring and evaluation of effectiveness must be incorporated, as appropriate, in program reviews. During program reviews, monitor and evaluate the results and effectiveness of consultation.

data.title: Training
data.landingpagecontent:
• Requirements for training for FS employees come from several sources
    • Department Regulation on Tribal Consultation and Collaboration (DR 1350-002, January 18, 2013);
    • Report to the Secretary of Agriculture, USDA Policy and Procedures Review and Recommendations:  Indian Sacred Sites (2012).
    • Specific trainings have been developed in compliance with requirements from recommendations
  • Training required by Departmental Regulation
    • Requirements  in DR 1350-002
      • USDA Officials charged with Consultation charged with Consultation
        • Tier I Level
        • Must complete a level training as set forth below:
          • Primary career SES
          • Key national and regional program Directors responsible for managing tribal relations within Forest Service
        • Tier II
          • Line Officers designated to conduct consultations with Tribes and/or ANC
          • Leaders of programs where those individuals would personally be involved in the consultation process
        • Tier III
          • All Forest Service employees – offered in Ag-Learn program, “Working Effectively with Tribal Governments” that can be accessed via the Internet
  • Training Recommended in the Sacred Sites Report
    • Section §13.2
      • Develop and implement core competencies for Line Officers and staff including:
        • Comprehensive training for Line Officers, staff and law enforcement personnel to provide
          • Knowledge to build respectful relationships
          • Use available tools for sacred site protection
          • Gain broader understanding of and competency with AI/AN laws, customs, traditions, values
          • Invite AI/AN people to assist in developing and delivering core curricula
      • Existing: Develop a catalog of existing training offered by Tribes and other entities
        • Work to increase FS attendance at tribally sponsored sessions
        • Work FS Grants and Agreements to develop agreements to simplify the acquisition of training services (FS, and USDA OTR)
      • Departmental:  Develop a training track to serve USDA at Departmental level
        • Make available for other USDA agencies to tailor to particular mission area (USDA OTR)
      • Agency Leadership/Regions
        • Develop training for Regional Line Officers and program area staffs, including Washington and regional levels using USDA and other available resources
          • Target audiences to address particular needs and concerns include:
            •  Acquisition Management staff
            •  FOIA officers
            • NEPA specialists
            • Law Enforcement Officers
            • Lands and Recreation Special Users
            • SP&F Staff
            • R&D Staff
      • Local:  Develop training for field based on national curricula
        • Target audience:
          • National Forest
          • Grasslands
            • Line Officers and Staff
            • Forest Supervisor's Office
            • District Rangers Office
            • Staff Officers at Forest and District levels
            • Field Employees
        • Training will include:
          • Workshops
          • Other relationship building efforts with partners
          • Draw on existing training resources
          • FS units will reach out to local Tribes for assistance in developing and delivering training to FS employees
          • FS units will coordinate with local Tribes when sponsoring FS workshops and/or training to include tribal perspectives.

data.title: Mediation
data.landingpagecontent: The Forest Service Line Officer with responsibilities for a particular decision and the Tribe’s representative are encouraged to use Alternative Dispute Resolution processes, including mediation, where a neutral third-party facilitates a mutually-agreeable solution.

data.title: Compensation
data.landingpagecontent:
• Agency officials are encouraged to facilitate tribal participation in Agency decision-making through financial support and other means.
  • No legal requirement to compensate for consultation or other involvement in FS activities
    • Forest Service may elect  to provide compensation to Tribes or tribal representatives for extraordinary situations and specialized expertise
  • Guidance for Compensation
    • Various authorities enable FS to enter into with Tribes
      • Grants
      • Contracts
      • Cooperative Agreements

for extraordinary consultation and specialized expertise such as traditional knowledge that could be incorporated into restoration efforts (FSM §1563.01 and FSH §1509.11)

  • NHPA also authorize Federal agencies to expend funds for historic preservation activities that includes working with Tribes.
  • Agency is not required to compensate a Tribe, the Agency can take a number of actions to assist with tribal participation.
  • Forest Service may request Tribe to provide specific information and documentation
    • Actual surveys and reports from Tribe would assist Agency management and responsibilities.
    • In this circumstance, Tribe may be acting as professional contractor or consultant providing work products or services, that Agency would normally compensate for.

data.title: Forest Service Tribal Policy Background
data.landingpagecontent:
Forest Service Tribal Policy Background

The Forest Service and federally recognized American Indian and Alaska Native entities share the value of restoring, sustaining, and enhancing the nation's forests and grasslands, providing, and sustaining benefits to the American people. In many cases, Indian tribes continue their traditional uses of the nation's forests and grasslands to sustain their cultural identity and continuity, and for economic development. The Government's trust responsibilities and treaty obligations make it essential that the Forest Service engages with Indian tribes in timely and meaningful consultation on policies that may affect Indian tribes. In addition to consultation, coordination and collaboration lead to information exchange, mutual understanding, informed decision-making, and mutual benefit. The value of collaboration is fully recognized within the Forest Service for all of its constituents, including Indian tribes as a support process for government-to-government consultation.

Forest Service and USDA Authorities and Rules

Forest Service Tribal Relations Directives (FSH 1509.13 and FSM 1500). The Forest Service Manual and Handbook for tribal relations were published on March 9, 2016. These directives institutionalize and tailor the agency-wide practices of tribal consultation and engagement.  Perhaps the most significant aspect of the new directives is the clear emphasis that every part of the Forest Service involves Tribal relations, and working with Tribes is part of every employee's job. https://www.fs.fed.us/spf/tribalrelations/authorities.shtml

Title 36, Code of Federal Regulations, Part 219 (Planning Rule). The Forest Service's 2012 Planning Rule provides direction for National Forest System NFS land management planning. Section 219.4 of the rule requires opportunities for public and Tribal participation and coordination throughout the planning process. https://www.fs.usda.gov/detail/planningrule/home/?cid=stelprd3828310

Food, Conservation, and Energy Act of 2008 (Public Law 110-234, "The Farm Bill").  The Farm Bill allows the Forest Service to provide federal financial assistance to local governments, Indian tribes, and qualified nonprofit organizations (including land trusts) to establish community forests that provide defined benefits, and includes the Culture and Heritage Cooperation Authority (see CHCA Guide,{Blue Block}). http://www.agriculture.senate.gov/issues/2008-farm-bill

USDA Departmental Regulation 1350-002, Tribal Consultation, Coordination, and Collaboration (DR), published January 18, 2013. The Regulation directs the USDA and its agencies to provide federally recognized Indian tribes the opportunity for government-to-government consultation and coordination in policy development and program activities which have direct and substantial effects on their Tribe. https://www.ocio.usda.gov/document/departmental-regulation-1350-002

Forest Products for Traditional and Cultural Purposes (2016).  This rule gives the Secretary of Agriculture discretionary authority to provide, free of charge, any trees, portions of trees, or forest products from National Forest System lands to federally recognized Indian tribes for traditional and cultural purposes. https://www.fs.fed.us/forestmanagement/traditional_cultural/index.shtml

Consultation and Coordination with Indian Tribes on Forest Planning. Regulations (36 CFR 219.4(a)) implementing the National Forest Management Act (NFMA) of 1976 (16 U.S.C. 472a et seq.) direct the Forest Service to consult with and coordinate forest planning with Indian tribes. The Forest Service must also consult with Alaska Native Corporations pursuant to PL 108-199 and PL 108-447. https://www.fs.usda.gov/Internet/FSE_DOCUMENTS/stelprdb5359591.pdf

Coordination with Tribal Land Use Management and Planning. The Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 (43 U.S.C. 1712(b)) requires the Forest Service to coordinate land use plans for NFS lands with the land use planning and management programs of and for Indian tribes. https://www.fs.usda.gov/Internet/FSE_DOCUMENTS/fseprd488457.pdf

National Forest Management Act's (NFMA) of 1976 (16 U.S.C. 472a et seq.), regulations (36 CFR 219.4(a)) implementing the NFMA direct the Forest Service to consult with and coordinate forest planning with Indian tribes. (See FSM 1563.01d.2) https://www.fs.fed.us/emc/nfma/includes/law.html

Tribal Forest Protection Act of 2004 (118 Stat. 870, P.L. 108-278, codified at25 U.S.C. 3115a, Tribal forest assets protection (TFPA)). The TFPA provides the authority for a Tribe and the Forest Service to enter into an agreement or contract to carry out a project to protect Indian forest land or rangeland that meets certain criteria. https://www.fs.fed.us/spf/tribalrelations/documents/policy/tfpa/USDA_FSBriefing_paper_TFPA_040505.pdf

Secure Rural Schools and Community Self-Determination Act of 2000; P.L. 106–393, 16 U.S.C. 500. The act allows the Forest Service to enter into contracts, grants, cooperative agreements, and partnership agreements with local governmental entities, tribal nations, individuals, nonprofit and for-profit organizations. https://www.fs.fed.us/payments/106-393_text.pdf

Culture and Heritage Cooperation Authority of 2008 (25 U.S.C. Chapter 32(A), section 3056(b)(A)). Requires the Forest Service to consult with affected Indian tribes before releasing culturally sensitive information.  It also includes provisions for reburial of human remains and cultural items, temporary closure for traditional and cultural purposes, forest products for traditional and cultural purposes, and prohibition on disclosure of information. https://www.fs.fed.us/spf/tribalrelations/authorities.shtml

Federal Land Policy and Management Act (FLPMA) of 1976 (43 U.S.C. 1701), requires coordinating of land use plans for lands in the National Forest System with the land use planning and management programs of and for Indian tribes. (See FSM 1563.01d.1). https://www.fs.usda.gov/Internet/FSE_DOCUMENTS/fseprd488457.pdf

Forest and Rangeland Renewable Resources Research Act of 1978, as amended (16 U.S.C. 1641-1646, Pub. L. 95-307). The Secretary of Agriculture may conduct, support, and cooperate in investigations, experiments, tests, and other activities deemed necessary to obtain, analyze, develop, demonstrate, and disseminate scientific information about protecting, managing, and using forest and rangeland resources in rural, suburban, and urban areas. The Secretary may cooperate with Indian tribes and is authorized to make competitive grants that will further research activities. https://www.fs.fed.us/emc/nfma/includes/range74.pdf

Watershed Restoration and Enhancement Agreement Authority (Wyden Amendment). The Forest Service uses this authority when it enters into Cooperative Agreements and Participating Agreements with Federal, tribal, State, and local governments; private and nonprofit entities; and landowners to improve fish, wildlife, and other resources on National Forest System lands within a watershed, and to reduce risk of natural disaster where public safety is threatened within the watershed. https://www.fs.fed.us/spf/coop/wyden/

National Authorities

National Historic Preservation Act of 1966 (NHPA) (54 U.S.C. 300101 et seq.), as amended in 1992. Requires Federal agency officials to consult with Indian tribes concerning the effects of undertakings on historic properties of traditional and cultural importance to Indian tribes. http://www.achp.gov/nhpa.pdf

Native American Graves Protection and Repatriation Act (NAGPRA).  Under NAGPRA the Forest Service has supported the repatriation of thousands of human remains and tens of thousands of funerary objects, sacred objects, and items of cultural patrimony. The Forest Service has also continued to support the reburial of approximately 5,000 sets of repatriated human remains on NFS lands under the Culture and Heritage Cooperation Authority (25 USC 32A). https://www.nps.gov/nagpra/

Presidential Memorandum of November 5, 2009. Presidential Memorandum to the heads of executive departments and agencies on Tribal Consultation. https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/memorandum-tribal-consultation-signed-president

Executive Order 13007, Indian Sacred Sites. This Executive Order directs Federal land management agencies, to the extent permitted by law, and not clearly inconsistent with essential agency functions, to accommodate access to and use of Indian sacred sites, to avoid affecting the physical integrity of such sites wherever possible, and, where appropriate, to maintain the confidentiality of sacred sites. http://www.achp.gov/EO13007.html

Executive Order 13175, Consultation and Coordination with Indian Tribal Governments, issued November 6, 2000, directs Federal agencies to establish regular and meaningful consultation and collaboration with Tribal officials in the development of Federal policies that have tribal implications, to strengthen the United States government-to-government relationships with Indian tribes. https://www.state.gov/documents/organization/136740.pdf

data.title: Definitions
data.landingpagecontent:
• Native American Graves Protection and Repatriation Act (NAGPRA), is a federal law passed in 1990.  Provides a process for museums and federal agencies to resolve possessory rights to certain Native American cultural items – human remains, funerary objects, sacred objects, or objects of cultural patrimony – to lineal descendants and cultural affiliated Indian Tribes and Native Hawaiian organizations.
    • NAGPRA does not, explicitly address reburial of Native American human remains repatriated by museums and federal agencies subject to NAGPRA.
    • NAGPRA provides for Indian tribes to take possession of the remains, but does not establish the authority to rebury on NFS lands
  •  National Historic Preservation ACT (NHPA)  was passed in 1966 and substantially amended in 1980 and 1992.  THE NHPA, requires all federal agencies to consider the effects of their projects and programs on historic properties and provides the structure and direction for all federal management of important cultural resources.
  • Archaeological Resources Protection Act (APRA) – passed in 1979 in recognition of  archaeological resources as in irreplaceable part of America’s heritage and that they were endangered increasingly  because of the escalating commercial value of a small portion of the contents of archaeological
  • Archaeological Resources Protection Act (ARPA) – passed in 1979, recognition of archaeological resources as an irreplaceable part of America’s heritage and that they were endangered increasingly because of escalating commercial value of a small portion of contents of archeological sites.
    • ARPA prohibits unauthorized excavation on federal and Indian lands, which adds a layer of protection to the repatriated and reburied items
    • ARPA establishes standards for permissible excavation, prescribes civil and criminal penalties, requires agencies to identify archeological sites and encourages cooperation between Federal agencies and private individuals.
  • Federal regulations (36 CFR §800 and 54 USC §300101 requires agencies to consult with various parties, (i.e. State and Tribal Historic Preservation Officers{SHPO/THPOs}, Indian tribes, or Native Hawaiian organizations and others – to determine if the proposed project may have an effect on a property listed on or eligible for listing on the National Register of Historic Places, and if so, what measures might be appropriate to minimize or mitigate that effect.
    • Many reburials will have very little or no effect to historic properties when reburials avoid the salient features of known historic properties, do not require physical site preparation and avoid extensive ground disturbance.
    • Such cases usually conclude with an official NHPA determination of “no effect” or “no historic properties affected” or “no adverse effect” (36 CFR 800.4(d) and 800.5)
  • Applying NAGPRA, NHPA and CHCA
    • Tribal governments and the Forest Service should have meaningful, government – to – government, discussion to determine.
      • Mutually acceptable solutions to protect and manage reburial sites
      • How Tribal government organizations will be involved in protecting and managing their reburial sties
      • What framework will be used for future collaborative efforts, with special emphasis on how to incorporate tribally-authorized members to help protect reburial sites
    • Native American and Alaska native concerns expressed most often during consultation or through personal testimony include:
      • Reburied remains may be disturbed in the future
      • Forest Service staff may interfere with tribal spiritual practices
      • Reburial of culturally unidentifiable human remains should be conducted with sensitivity and in a traditionally appropriate manner

data.title: Line Officers' Resonsibilities for Re-burial
data.landingpagecontent:
Responsibility for authorizing reburials on NFS lands, resides with the Regional Foresters.  Regional Foresters may delegate that authority in writing, to Forest and Grassland Supervisors under their supervision.

  • Timeframe:  ensure that requests for reburial are addressed in a timely manner.
  • Consultation:  When authorizing reburials, consult with the lineal descendants or culturally affiliated process. This my include site protection and management protocols.
    • An understanding may take the form of correspondence rather than a formal MOU.
    • This agreement may include reburial of human remains and associated funerary objects (FSH §1509.13)
  • Notification:  Inform the appropriate law enforcement agents of reburial activities in order to protect reburial sites through monitoring and surveillance activities.
  • Avoid Conflicting Uses:  Identify areas where anticipated uses will not cause future impacts or physical harm to the site and in consultation, a location that is consistent with tribal cultural, spiritual and religious requirements for reburial purposes.
  • Mitigation Measures:  Develop and implement mitigation measures in consultation with tribal governments, clans and indiviuals to minimize or avoid adverse impacts to reburial sites that may be caused by particular land uses. Ensure the measures will be implemented for the long run
  • Coordination and Reporting:  A critical first step is to ensure that all requests for reburial are reported and coordinated with the Regional Tribal rlatins program Manager, Regional Heritage Resources Program Manager, and appropriate law enforcement personnel.

data.title: Management Tools - Reburial
data.landingpagecontent:
• Placement of remains in a historic property, under the provisions of NHPA and ARPA. Both laws provide for additional security of the site and associated information.
  • When remains are known to have been removed from a specific site, evaluate, on a case-by-case basis. Alternative locations should be considered if a reburial would cause adverse effect to known properties.
  • When remains are not reburied at the site of their original interment, consider alternative location at another historic property; evaluate reburial plans on a case-by-case bases.
  • During consultation, provide information to Indian tribes, clans, and family members regarding appropriate reburial locations, including the location where the remains were removed. 
    • It is important to determine the status of the reburial location in regard to the Sacred Sites Executive Order 13007, the Forest Service must depend on Indian tribes to identify and designate sacred sites.
  • Redirect public use away from reburial sites, including those not located on a historical property. This may require landscape level consideration of potential land and resource management actions.
  • Restrict Permit Issuance – Deny or redirect permit for use of areas or materials that contain reburial sites.
  • During NF and Grassland planning process, ensure that consideration is given to special areas identified by Indian tribes.
    • Create planning information and directin that enable and protects areas suitable for reburial, as well as previous reburial sites.

data.title: Confidentiality
data.landingpagecontent:
• FS personnel should ensure that information about reburial locations is kept confidential by consulting person –to-person. This will ensure that the appropriate FS staff and Indian tribe, or descendent community retains documentation.
    • Restriction of access to information will help keep reburial locations protected from future development or disturbance.
    • Agency must provide for the long-term security of the confidential information and ensure that the locational information is available during planning efforts.

data.title: R&D Roadmap implements goals and objective outline in agency-wide Tribal Relations Strategic Plan
Increase Tribal and Indigenous Values an Knowedge
Communicate and connect existing partnershps and edeavers with Tribes, Native Groups and Tribal Colleges
Report address traditional issues managed by FS
Tribal Community Engagement for Delivery on Agency's Strategic Plan
What is a Sacred Site
data.landingpagecontent:
“. . . any specific, discrete, narrowly delineated location on Federal land that is identified by an Indian Tribe, or Indian individual determined to be an appropriately authoritative representative of an Indian religion, as sacred by virtue of its established religious significance to, or ceremonial use by, an Indian religion; provided that the tribe or appropriately authoritative representative of an Indian religion has informed the agency of the existence of such a site.”

Agencies are required to, where appropriate, maintain the confidentiality of sacred sites.  Executive Order 13007 establishes that Indian Tribes and appropriate representatives of AI/AN religions (not the agencies) identify which locations are sacred sites under the Executive Order).

Basic:  Under Sacred Sites EO, does not require that a Sacred Site have material cultural components; it could be a natural spring, or rock shelter, a landscape, or even a body of water, as examples.

data.title: USDA FS Sacred Sites Policy
data.landingpagecontent:
• Accommodate access to access to and ceremonial use of Indian sacred sites by Indian religious practitioners
  • Avoid adversely affecting they physical integrity of such sacred sites
  • Maintain the confidentiality of sacred sites where appropriate
  • Implement procedures to execute these provisions
  • Ensure reasonable notice is provided of proposed actions that may restrict future access to or ceremonial use of, or will adversely affect the physical integrity of sacred sites.

data.title: Can be a Spirtual Connection
data.landingpagecontent:
• Spiritual connection between tribal people and their ancestors (including all aspects of the natural world) is expressed through the existence and use of cultural resources or traditional ceremonial sites left in place and in context.
  • Can be:
    • Burial Places
    • Sacred areas
    • Historic Trails
    • Travel Corridors
    • Subsistence locations
  • A sacred site is not necessarily a place, but may be a geographic feature connected to a creation story.
  • A sacred site is not necessarily a place where anyone goes
    • Example:  ANWR (Arctic national Wildlife Refuge) contains

Caribou birthing grounds
Those grounds are sacred to most Athabascan people and they do not go there

  • Knowledge of sites is often private and cannot be shared with non-tribal members, or the public
  • It is important to understand the nature of private knowledge among indigenous communities
  • Some things cannon be share with outsiders without violating cultural customs and beliefs

data.title: Sacred Sites and the National Historic Preservation Act (NHPA)
data.landingpagecontent:
• Federal law passed in 1966 that governs historic preservation policy of the federal government
  • BASICS:  A Sacred Site might not be protected under the NHPA, if it does not have a material, cultural component, such an archeological site, or structure.
  • Created the Advisory Council on Historic Preservation (ACHP), an independent agency of the United States government that oversees federal preservation efforts.
  • NHPA and its regulations are the most important tools for protecting historic sites affected by projects undertaken, funded or regulated by the federal government
  • Section 106 of the NHPA requires agencies to consider the impact of undertakings they carry out, fund or regulate on historic properties and to give the ACHP the opportunity to comment on those undertakings. 
  • Regulations established pursuant to §106, 36 CFR 800, are that federal agencies
    • Make attempts to identify historic properties that might be impacted by their actions
    • The attempts include seeking input from knowledgeable sources
    • Make attempts to avoid, minimize or mitigate any impacts their actions may have on historic properties that might be impacted by their actions
      • These attempts including seeking input from knowledgeable sources, including Tribes
    • Make attempts to avoid, minimize or mitigate any impacts their actions may have on historic properties
    • Consult with interested parties on how to avoid, minimize, or mitigate impacts to historic properties
    • Consult with the appropriate federally recognized Indian Tribes when Native American historic properties are involved

These requirements are highly significant when it comes to preserving Native American historical sites.  The requirement to identify historic properties makes it less probable that these resources will be unintentionally destroyed.

Section 106 of NHPA – ensures that historic preservation is considered in federal project planning. Work with State Historic Preservation Officers and Tribal Historic Preservation Officers as well as, Federal Preservation Officers should all collaborate during the process. The Section 106 review process is used to determine a federal project’s effect on historic properties.

Link to 36 CFR 800, from Advisory Council on Historic Preservation

data.title: About the FS Tribal Relations Strategic Plan
data.landingpagecontent:
• Supports the FS national priorities and aligns with USDA Secretary’s Strategic Goals
  • Tribal Relations Strategic Plan – goals match goals in USDA Forest Service Strategic Plan
    • Sustain Nations Forests and Grasslands
    • Deliver benefits to the Public
    • Apply Knowledge Globally
    • Excel as High Performing Agency

data.title: Summary of Goals and Objectives
data.landingpagecontent:
The strategic plan is organized by the following:

  1. Goals - high-level goals are derived from the Forest Service mission and fiduciary responsibility to Tribes.
    • What are the key values we are trying to address?
    • What is the problem you are faced with?
    • Why are we addressing this topic?
    • What does success look like?
  2. Objectives - actionable statements that focus on what must be accomplished to achieve the goals
    • What are the most important actions and the order in which they are accomplished?
    • Who is the target of the actions?
    • Who is affected by the action?
    • Who is accountable?
    • Where the overlap is (is there opportunity to double up on priority actions?
    • Where are the roadblocks?
  3. Outcomes - provide the quantitative or qualitative measureable effect the program will accomplish
    • What are the real and lasting changes we want to produce?
    • What needs to be catalyzed or changed?
    • What do FS employees most need?
    • What are we missing?
  4. Focused Actions – are targeted actions to achieve the outcomes
    • Will directions and policy need to change?
    • Is the product within the purview of the Agency? The Department?
    • How do products accomplish the objectives or outcomes?

data.title: Strategic Goal: Sustain
data.landingpagecontent:
• Strategic Goal: Sustain Sovereignty Through Shared Stewardship
    • Goal – Sustain Our Nation’s Forest and Grasslands
      • Objective
        • 1.A. Build
        • Strengthen
        • Uphold nation to nation relationship
        • That sustain tribal sovereignty; and
        • Help meet the Agency’s trust responsivity and treaty obligations.
      • Objective
        • 1.B Engage in shared stewardship of our Nations lands, including:
        • Tribal and Forest service lands and resources to support healthy and resilient forests and grasslands
        • Benefit tribal communities and help the Forest Service better accomplish its mission

data.title: Strategic Goal: Deliver
data.landingpagecontent:
• Strategic Goal:  Deliver Benefits to the Tribal Communities and the Public
    • Goal – Deliver Benefits to the Public
      • Objective
        • 2.A Facilitate delivery of benefits to tribal communities and public
        • 2.B  Strengthen availability
          • Access
          • Use
          • Resilience of tribally important resources and places
        • 2.C Leverage partners’ capabilities

data.title: Strategic Goal: Apply
data.landingpagecontent:
• Strategic Goal:  Apply Knowledge Inclusively
    • Goal – Apply Knowledge Globally
      • Objective
        • 3.A  Facilitate the appropriate and ethical gathering and exchange of knowledge and perspectives that lead to beneficial actions on forests and grasslands across boundaries
        • 3.B  Promote diversity and inclusion within the agency in support of the Forest Service Strategic Plan Management Objective “Recruit a diverse workforce”

data.title: Strategic Goal: Excel
data.landingpagecontent:
• Strategic Goal:  Excel in Tribal Relations Leadership
    • Excel as a High-performing Agency
      • Objective
        • 4.A  Showcase outstanding examples of collaboration with Tribes
          • Promoting positive agency engagement to enhance  tribal relations
        • 4.B  Continuously improve how the Forest Service:
          • Creates
          • Maintains
          • Improves Tribal relations.
        • 4.C  Enhance the Forest Service’s ability to
          • Maintain and accountable process for
          • Consultation and other interactions with Tribes

data.title: Strategic Plan: Organized by Goals, Objectives, Focused Actions
data.landingpagecontent:
• Goals
    • What are the key values we are trying to address?
    • What is the problem you are faced with?
    • Why are we address this topic?
    • What does success look like?
  • Objectives
    • What are the most important actions and the order in which they are accomplished?
    • Who is the target of the actions?
      • Who is affect by the action?
      • Who is accountable?
    • Where is the overlap
      • Is there opportunity to double up on priority actions?
    • Where are the roadblocks?
  • Outcomes
    • What are the real and lasting changes we want to produce
    • What needs to be catalyzed or changed?
    • What do FS employees most need?
    • What are we missing?
  • Focused Actions
    • Will directions and policy need to change?
    • Is the product within the purview of the:
      • Agency
      • Department

 

    • How do products accomplish the:
      • Objectives; or
      • Outcomes

data.title: Vision for Tribal Relations in Forest Service
data.landingpagecontent:
• FS recognizes and supports the sovereignty of American Indians and Alaska Native tribal nations and self-determination of tribal peoples through:
    • Building
    • Maintaining
    • Enhancing government to government relationships with Tribal Governments
  • FS engages inclusively with:
    • People in mutual respect
    • Active collaboration
    • Share stewardship
  • FS promotes
    • Meaningful nation-to-nation consultation with tribal nations; and
    • Communities in ways that foster free, prior and informed consent
  • FS Implementation of agency programs and activities in a manner that:
    • Honors Indian Tribes’ treaty rights
    • Fulfills the agency’s trust responsibilities; and
    • Respects each independent tribal nation and their cultures.
  • Summary of Goals and Objectives
    • Sustain Sovereignty Through Shared Stewardship
      • Objective:  1A – Build, strengthen, and uphold nationa to nation relationships that sustain tribal sovereignty and help meet the Agency’s trust responsibility and treaty obligations
      • 1B – Engage in shared stewardship of our Nation’s lands, including tribal and FS lands and resources, to support healthy and resilient forests and grasslands that benefit tribal communities and help the FS better accomplish its mission.
    • Deliver Benefits to Tribal Communities and the Public
      • Objective 2.A – Facilitate delivery of benefits to tribal communities and the public
      • 2.B – Strengthen availability, access, use and resilence of tribally important resources and places
      • 2.C – Leverage partners capabilities.
    • Apply Knowledge Inclusively
      • 3.A – Facilitate the appropriate and ethical gathering and exchange of knowledge and perspectives that lead to beneficial actions on forests and grasslands across boundaries.
      • 3. B – Promote diversity and inclusion within the agency in support of the Forest service Strategic Plan Management Objective “Recruit a Diverse Workforce”
    • Excel in Tribal Relations Leadership
      • Showcase outstanding examples of collaboration with Tribes, promoting positive agency engagement to enhance tribal relations
      • Continuously improve how the Forest Service creates, maintains, and improves tribal relations.
      • Enhance the Forest Service ability to maintain an accountable process for its consultation and other interactions with Tribes.

data.title: Mission of the Forest Service
data.landingpagecontent:
• Consistent with the FS mission, the Forest Service expresses a culture that:
    • Uses sound advice an appropriate assistance to enhance and maintain important relationships with Tribes and indigenous communities
    • Recognizes and supports the inherent sovereign status and reserved rights of Tribes
    • Honors the Federal trust responsibility to Tribes
    • Excels at conducting substantive and meaningful consultative processes with Tribes
    • Supports Tribal Governments’ and indigenous communities’ rights to pursue and enhance the vitality of their cultures, economies and lands.
    • Promotes collaborative natural and cultural resource management, including protecting and providing access to tribal sacred places.
    • Encourages use of traditional knowledge in combination with the best Western science and technology.
    • Advances American Indians and Alaska Natives in the workforce.
    • Respects and helps maintain tribal connections to traditional landscapes.
    • Facilitates information exchange between Tribes and Forest Service researchers.

data.title: Sustain our Nation's Forests and Grasslands
data.landingpagecontent:
By recognizing and supporting the sovereignty of tribal nations and expertise of tribal peoples, the FS can enhance shared stewardship to better sustain the Nation’s forests and grasslands.

  • Provides channel for Tribes to be involved in FS programs and activities
  • Create benefits within the agency’s mission responsive to local and affiliated community needs and interests.

Objectives/Outcomes

  • Objective 1.A – Build, strengthen and uphold nation to nation relationships that sustain tribal sovereignty and help meet the agency’s trust responsibility and treat obligations.
    • Outcomes – Tribal nations and the FS engage in relationships that reinforce mutual interests and shared decision making.
  • Objective 1.B – Engage in shared stewardship of our Nation’s lands, including tribal and FS lands and resources, to support healthy and resilient forests and grasslands that benefit tribal communities and help the Forest Service better accomplish its mission.
    • Tribal Governments and tribal communities sustainably receive cultural, social, economic, and ecological benefits from actions taken in partnership with the Forest Service.  The FS receives tribal expertise, capacity and resources through partnerships that help the agency sustain the Nation’s forests and grasslands, and fulfill the agency’s objective to strengthen communities.

Focused Actions

  • Apply the FS mission in ways that fulfill the agency’s trust responsibilities and treaty obligations.
  • Help protect tribal reserved rights as they pertain to FS lands and resources, as applied through policies, programs and projects
  • Consult early and often to ensure all topics are on the table and relationships are maintained
  • Convene regularly scheduled interactions between tribal and FS unit leadership to maintain productive relationships and collaborative opportunities
  • Develop and enhance bilateral agreements
  • Foster projects and partnerships that result in completion of mutually desired outcomes
  • Expand use of FS general authorities and tribally specific authorities such as TPA, CHCA
  • Develop and implement FS activities that highlight, engage and promote traditional ecological knowledge, preserve traditional cultures, and contribute to community well-being
Develop and distribute case studies of success resulting from agency and tribal partnerships, with consent of Tribes.

data.title: Deliver Benefits to the Public
data.landingpagecontent:
FS provides goods and services locally, nationally, and internationally.

  • Trust responsibility and treaty obligations, FS have particular focus on benefits we provide to Tribal communities.
  • Enhance focus by connecting agency’s mission to traditional tribal lifeways and values
  • Various programs serve to improve intra-agency coordination, increase program delivery efficiency, maximize scarce program resources, and solve problems through cooperation with partners

Objectives/Outcomes

  • Objective 2.A – Facilitate delivery of benefits to tribal communities and the public
    • Outcome – Tribal nations and their constituent communities receive the benefits of the FS land management actions, expertise, and knowledge.
    • These benefits span jurisdictions to accomplish desired protections, conservation and uses
  • Objective 2.B – Strengthen availability, access, use and resilience of tribally important resources and places.
    • Outcome – Tribal citizens have appropriate access to important resources and sacred places on National Forest System lands. Projects and partnerships promote connections between the agency’s mission and traditional native lifeways.
  • Objective 2.C – Leverage partners’ capabilities
    • Outcome – Improve intra-agency and inter-agency coordination, and expand partnerships with third parties, to create efficiencies in program delivery in support of the FS mission to promote and develop markets for forest products.

Focused Actions

  • Review and revise policies to better reflect tribal engagement and participation in FS decision making, programs and projects
  • Seek opportunities to partner with Tribes in work across boundaries and leverage resources to accomplish together what we could not each do on our own.
  • Work with Tribes to identify barriers to effective partnerships and consultation
  • Develop and distribute useful information about FS actions and opportunities
  • Identify and work with partners who can help create benefits for the FS
  • When the FS is unable to meet a Tribe’s requests, be clear and transparent in explaining to the Tribe why this is not possible
  • Use appropriate conflict resolution processes when disagreements between a Tribe and the FS occur.
  • Continue implementation of the 2012 Sacred Site Report recommendations
  • Expand use of FS general authorities, and tribally specific authorities such as TPA, and CHCA, in support of connecting Tribes to traditional places and resources
  • Implement FS programs, including Federal financial assistance and technical assistance programs that apply to Tribal Governments and tribal communities
  • Explore new ways, including research and management, to provide appropriate tribal access and use of FS resources.
  • Expand partnership agreements
  • Develop and nurture new partnerships
  • Develop strong personal and organization relationships with tribally supporting organizations

data.title: Apply Knowledge Globally
data.landingpagecontent:
The Forest Service is a provider and consumer of knowledge about management, leadership, and resources from many diverse sources.

  • Western Science
  • Citizen Science
  • Native Science
  • Traditional Knowledge - Incorporating Tribal knowledge can improve the agency’s resources management decisions and outcomes
  • Forest Service must balance legal obligation to support tribal nations, while at same time delivering our mission

Objectives/Outcomes

  • Objective 3.A – The appropriate and ethical gathering and exchange of knowledge and perspectives from tribal citizens that lead to beneficial actions
    • Outcome – Tribal knowledge and wisdom are respected, protected, encouraged, and appropriately used in Forest Service activities. 
    • Tribal communities, FS personnel, and our partners engage in productive and positive relationships that lead to mutual understanding, respect and participation in activities that are mutually beneficial.
  • Objective 3.B – Promote diversity, and inclusion within the agency, in support of the FS Strategic Plan Management Objective “Recruit a diverse workforce.”
    • Outcome – Creativity and effectiveness in Forest Service decision making are enhanced through including and sharing of diverse experiences, knowledge, and perspectives of indigenous peoples.

Focused Actions

  • Facilitate transfer of knowledge between the FS and Tribes, sharing Western science and traditional ecological knowledge to leverage the benefits of both
  • Engage Tribes early in forest plan revisions and research plans
  • Engage Tribes early in initial planning of programs and projects
  • Engage Tribes in Forest Service research and technical assistance activities that meet tribal interests and requests
  • Coordinate with Human Resources and Civil Rights staffs to outreach and recruit American Indian and Alaska Natives
  • Facilitate and support Forest Service employees direct interactions with Tribal Government staffs and tribal culture bearers
  • Create and distribute appropriate training materials and relevant publications that increase FS personnel knowledge, understanding and competencies in tribal relations

data.title: Excel as a High Performing Agency
data.landingpagecontent:
Tribal relations is the responsibility of every FS employee.  Tribal foundation is place through

  • Tribal Relations Manual and Handbook
  • Top-level Leadership orientation
  • Line Officers
  • Other personnel throughout the agency
  • Striving for outstanding public service is part of the FS organizational culture

Objectives/Goals

  • Objective 4.A – Showcase outstanding examples of collaborations with Tribes, promoting positive agency engagement to enhance tribal relations
    • Outcome – Forest Service leadership and staff, tribal leaders, tribal staff, and other partners are excited about and active in enhancing existing partnerships and creating new ones.  These partnerships will produce:
      • Resilient ecosystems
      • Enhanced cultural resilience
      • Better economies, all benefiting Indian Country and all components of the FS
  • Objective 4.B – Continuously improve how the FS creates, maintains and improves tribal relations.
    • Outcome – Forest Service employees function as a highly developed, world class team that supports the FS mission and the agency’s contributions to the well-being of tribal communities and the general American public.
  • Objective 4.C – Enhance the Forest Service’s ability to maintain an accountable process for its consultation and other interactions with Tribes.
    • The FS is able to report to Tribes and USDA our level of activity in tribal relations:
      • Allocation of resources
      • Conditions or Relationships improvement
      • FS in compliance with Executive Order 13175, Consultation and Coordination with Indian Tribal Governments

data.title: Regional Tribal Relations
data.landingpagecontent: Coming Soon...
